message: I voted against the war in Iraq, and knew it was the right vote then, and most people recognize it was the right vote today. Experience is important, but so is judgement.

Trump "The vicious snake"

https://www.bing.com/videos/search?q=video+the+vicious+snake&view=detail&mid=394F5B18A8260C4F127A394F5B18A8260C4F127A&FORM=VRRTAP

Hillary Clinton still using the "evolve" crutch as a rationale for having bad judgment, botching tons of progressive votes before flip flopping (Iraq, tpp, doma, nafta, wall street, keystone pipeline, patriot act, citizens united, Libya, banking). Unacceptable! We expect good judgment from the start, the new high bar set by Bernie Sanders, who doesn't need to "evolve" over and over and over. 

Hillary fully supported Bill, crushing black communities with: crack cocaine sentencing disparity law, welfare reform, and nafta... 

Bernie Sanders fights for minorities. 

Then:

Bernie marched on Washington with MLK Jr. in 1963 and was at the "I have a dream" speech. He fought for desegregated housing in Chicago in the 60's and he was arrested for protesting against segregation. He campaigned and endorsed rev. Jesse Jackson in 84' and 88'

Hillary Clinton supported republican Barry Goldwater in the 1964 presidential election; Goldwater voted against the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (supporting segregation). In the 80's Hillary was a lawyer for Walmart from 86-92', working to DISENFRANCHISE the poor via walmart's anti-union / low-wage policy, protecting the Walton family wealth. Walmart then supported the Clinton's for Bill's 92' campaign.

Now:

Bernie: conduct automatic federal investigations for anyone who dies in police custody (for Sandra Bland et al.). Hillary has nothing here.

Bernie: allow states to legalize marijuana and remove marijuana as a federally classified drug to help those affected most (minorities). Hillary wants to put marijuana on a lower drug enforcement classification but doesn’t want it legalized. So minorities would still disproportionately go to jail and tax payers would still pay for a broke justice system. And needed funding wouldn't go to help schools and local gov. programs from taxing legal marijuana sales.

Bernie: provide "postal-banking" so basic banking services can be accessed by ALL communities, especially those underserved, minority communities where, instead of banks, people often must cash checks at pay day lenders for 50-200% interest because there are no bank branches. Postal banking is something many advanced countries (Japan, Germany, Korea, NZ...) already offer in addition to commercial banking. Hillary wants..... well, I'm not sure how she plans on helping minority communities??

Bernie: all public colleges and universities to be tuition-free by paying for it with a tax on wall street speculation. Hillary does not want tuition-free higher ed. but wants "debt free tuition" where broke families and teens still need to pay. = barrier to entrance

Bernie: universal healthcare for ALL, as a right, not a privilege. Hillary wants to strengthen Obamacare, which serves some.

Bernie: raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour and the top 1-2% will pay for it. Hillary wants to raise it to $12 an hour. $12 an hour is not even a living wage for a single person and doesn't account for inflation. How is $12 an hour for a single parent??

A superhardworking, super passionate man almost 3/4 of a century old is fighting hard, selflessly, relentlessly to pursue a better future for not just us, but our future children and grandchildren. If it were any other ordinary politician (or businessman), after over have half a century of hard-served public service, they'd most probably be off relaxing on an island sipping Mai Tai's instead of campaigning so hard with NOTHING to benefit from it directly in their lifetime. Bernie Sanders is a statistical anomaly, or miracle as the superstitious would put it. Let's not ignore him, let's not take him for granted and watch him disappear cuz we may never get this chance again to improve our lives so drastically for future generations to come. Let us help him win this common sense fight for basic human rights of free health and education for the common people. #delayedgratification

Median income would soar by more than $22,000. Nearly 26 million jobs would be created. The unemployment rate would fall to 3.8%. This enhanced government spending would increase demand on businesses, who would then hire more workers to meet their needs. The increase in employment will prompt people to buy more, leading other businesses to hire. #socialdemocracy

Today you’re here on Facebook, using social media, as you do most days.  Your generation knows these venues as a part of your regular day, and normal routine.  You’re intelligent, and the future holds no limits to where you can go, or what you can do.  You’ve educated yourself, and grown to be a supporter of Bernie Sanders in his candidacy for President.  Bravo!  

Some reading this will spend many hours clicking a keyboard to voice their support for the Senator.  Some might talk to their friends or family, co-workers or even fraternity or sorority families about the positive future his plan provides, and what it means to so many people.  From the homeless and poor to the average American family, you’ve discovered an individual whose career and mission have been, and are, to improve the lives we, and future generations, will live.  You’ve selected your candidate, and you believe in him.  

IT’S NOT ENOUGH.  

None of these things have the same meaning as actually casting a vote.  Here we are, just a few events into the primary season, and Bernie has done okay, but with you getting out and voting, he’ll do even better, and bring the beginnings of a promising future to our nation.  It won’t happen automatically, and won’t be instant; but without your efforts and your actual vote, it won’t happen at all.  You’ve taken the first steps.  Please, don’t stop now.  Register if you haven’t, vote by mail if need be, and get to the polls or caucuses.  Yes, it’s going to take a little effort, and a small portion of a single day, but that’s a minuscule price to pay to brighten your future, and the futures of those who will follow you, as well as those of us who have preceded you, and served this country to be sure you would have this opportunity.  

Thank you for reading, and please vote.                                           SHB

Interesting Fact: In 1994, the Republicans pushed a 10 Point "Contract with America." This effort was so successful in concept that it won them back control of the Senate for the 1st time in 40 years. However, it got shot down by the Democrats and Clinton administration. The concept of a "Contract with America" could still bring about real change - the kind of change the Sanders campaign stands on. Or perhaps, Americans really needs a "Contract with Congress" that stipulates term limits and lobbying restrictions. It's time for a commitment on paper that Americans can read and enforce. After all, what other career do you know of that pays a lifetime salary plus untold bonuses without an employment contract?
And we're going to keep doing it by putting Trump in the white house. #2016TrumpforPresident.

"Who Is Bernie Sanders?"
Posted On Feb 22 2016 By : Dr. Sarah Condor "Bernard Sanders grew up in Brooklyn in an orthodox Jewish family, attended a Hebrew school, later studied at Brooklyn College and transferred to Chicago University for a BA in Political Science, his only degree. He attributes his “mediocrity” to lack of interest in studies, because he wanted to be more involved in community organizing, going out, not staying home with books. Another reason? He admired Hitler, as he says, for the power Hitler had over people. He was fascinated with this power and always wanted to follow a political career leading to such a position.

As a Young Socialist (member of the Socialist Party of America) he organized the first Chicago sit-in, protested housing discrimination, and marched on Washington in 1963 to hear Martin Luther King in person. Of course, he met Saul Alinsky and Noam Chomsky, even before he ran as a Democrat for Mayor of Burlington. No-one ran against him on the Republican side… He was a good mayor, they say, improving all public areas, making everything he could public: park, science center, embankment, housing…

You can do that with a small town or even a small country, such as Denmark (population 5mil.), not with a country the size of the United States! Why? We want the individual to have the power. The power of each of us rests in how capable we are, how hard we work, what we earn and reinvest of our own volition. In short, private property equals freedom. Take away property, collectivize it, you have a nation of slaves." "Finally, Jane Sanders O’Meara was a social worker and community organizer in Burlington, where Sanders was Mayor. She became President of Burlington College, but had to retire in 4 years, fired for causing “a toxic and disruptive environment.” Her salary was $160K, severance pay $200K. Today, Jane Sanders O’Meara is the one who decides everything regarding Sanders’ policy and appearances. As he says, she is “one of his key advisors, administrative & policy adviser, chief of staff and media buyer” and, interestingly, Sanders credited her with drafting more than 50 pieces of “his” Congressional legislature.

Shall we vet our candidates or stay complacent and elect another puppet in the hands of political hacks and ideologues – this time the one who looks up to Hitler and Marx as paragons of political power?" http://politichicks.com/2016/02/who-is-bernie-sanders/

WE NEED EVERY VOTE 

The commitment to show up to vote for Bernie in every state as we grow our tribe across the country is critical.  It's the major reason we came short in Nevada and Ohio.

Key takeaways learned in Obama vs. Clinton race.

Marketing is tribal.  Barack Obama had a challenge . He knew that the traditional base for Democratic candidates wouldn't be sufficient to get him elected (it had failed John Kerry). So he too set out to weave a new tribe, a tribe that included progressives, the center, younger religious voters, weary veterans, internationalists, Nobel prize winners, black voters and others.

Motivating the committed outperforms persuading the uncommitted. The unheralded success factor of Obama's campaign is the get out the vote effort. Every marketer can learn from this. It's easier (far easier) to motivate the slightly motivated than it is to argue with those that either ignore you or are predisposed to not like you.

Bill Clinton ran on the promise to "end welfare as we know it," a total repudiation of the FDR/LBJ legacy. With the help of republicans, Clinton was eventually successful in drastically cutting the welfare program.

 Clinton also signed important deregulatory bills into law, like the Commodities Futures Modernization Act and the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. 

Most economists blame one or both of these pieces of legislation with directly facilitating the housing crisis in 2008 (there is a robust debate about which one is more important, with economists like Paul Krugman leaning toward CFMA as the more important one while Robert Reich argues GLBA). Hillary Clinton supported these measures during the 1990s and has in some cases continued to voice support for them. Think about that  Bill signed all of this legislation into law. Bernie Sanders was against welfare reform and GLBA at the time (he voted for CFMA-it was snuck into an 11,000 page omnibus spending bill at the last minute).

On economic policy, contemporary establishment democrats have more in common with contemporary republicans than they do with the FDR/LBJ democrats. Carter and Clinton took the party away from economic progressives. The Democratic Party, which was once the party that saw economic inequality and poverty as the core causes of economic instability, now sees inequality and poverty as largely irrelevant.

Instead of eliminating inequality and poverty to fuel the capitalist system and produce strong economic growth, establishment democrats now largely agree with establishment republicans that the problem is a lack of support for business investment.

Hillary Clinton is a neoliberal building on the legacy of Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton. She doesn't understand the pivotal role inequality plays in creating economic crisis and reducing economic growth. She has been taken in by a fundamentally right wing paradigm, and if she is elected she will continue to lead the Democratic Party down that path.

Bernie Sanders is a democratic socialist building on the legacy of Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson. He understands that inequality is the core structural factor in economic crisis and that growth in real wages and incomes is required for robust, sustainable economic growth.

It doesn't matter which one is more experienced, or which one's policies are more likely to pass congress, or which one is more likely to win a general election, or which one is a man and which one is a woman. This is not about just this election, or just the next four years.

This is about whether the Democratic Party is going to care about inequality for the next decade.

We are making a historical decision between two distinct ideological paradigms, not a choice between flavors of popcorn. This is important. Choose carefully.
